original_text: Classical, two-dimensional sigma models on compact symmetric spaces G/H are integrable by virtue of conserved quantities which can arise as integrals of local or non-local functions of the underlying fields (the accounts in [1–5] contain references to the extensive literature). Since these models are asymptotically free and strongly coupled in the infrared, their quantum properties are not straightforward to determine. Nevertheless, following Lüscher [6], Abdalla, Forger and Gomes showed [7] that, in a G/H sigma model with H simple,11Here, and throughout this Letter, we shall use simple to mean that the corresponding Lie algebra has no non-trivial ideals. Hence U(1) is simple in our terminology, in addition to the usual non-Abelian simple groups of the Cartan–Killing classification [13]. the first conserved non-local charge survives quantization (after an appropriate renormalization [6–8]), which suffices to ensure quantum integrability of the theory. By contrast, calculations using the 1/N expansion reveal anomalies that spoil the conservation of the quantum non-local charges in the CPN−1=SU(N)/SU(N−1)×U(1) models for N>2, and in the wider class of theories based on the complex Grassmannians SU(N)/SU(n)×SU(N−n)×U(1) for N>n>1 [9].
original_translation: Los modelos sigma clásicos bidimensionales en espacios simétricos compactos G/H son integrables gracias a las cantidades conservadas que pueden surgir como integrales de funciones locales o no locales de los campos subyacentes (los informes en [1–5] contienen referencias a la extensa literatura). Dado que estos modelos son asintóticamente libres y fuertemente acoplados en el infrarrojo, sus propiedades cuánticas no son fáciles de determinar. Sin embargo, siguiendo a Lüscher [6], Abdalla, Forger y Gomes demostraron [7] que, en un modelo sigma G/H con H simple, 11Aquí, y a lo largo de esta carta, usaremos simple para referirnos a que el álgebra de Lie correspondiente no tiene ideales no triviales. Por lo tanto, U(1) es simple en nuestra terminología, además de los habituales grupos simples no abelianos de la clasificación de Cartan-Killing [13]. La primera carga no local conservada sobrevive a la cuantización (después de una renormalización apropiada [6-8]), lo cual es suficiente para garantizar la integrabilidad cuántica de la teoría. Por el contrario, los cálculos utilizando la expansión 1/N revelan anomalías que arruinan la conservación de las cargas cuánticas no locales en los modelos CPN−1=SU(N)/SU(N−1)×U(1) para N>2, y en la amplia clase de teorías basadas en los Grassmannianos complejos SU(N)/SU(n)×SU(N−n)×U(1) para N>n>1 [9].
original_sentences: Classical, two-dimensional sigma models on compact symmetric spaces G/H are integrable by virtue of conserved quantities which can arise as integrals of local or non-local functions of the underlying fields (the accounts in [1–5] contain references to the extensive literature).
Since these models are asymptotically free and strongly coupled in the infrared, their quantum properties are not straightforward to determine.

Nevertheless, following Lüscher [6], Abdalla, Forger and Gomes showed [7] that, in a G/H sigma model with H simple,11Here, and throughout this Letter, we shall use simple to mean that the corresponding Lie algebra has no non-trivial ideals.

Hence U(1) is simple in our terminology, in addition to the usual non-Abelian simple groups of the Cartan–Killing classification [13]. the first conserved non-local charge survives quantization (after an appropriate renormalization [6–8]), which suffices to ensure quantum integrability of the theory.

By contrast, calculations using the 1/N expansion reveal anomalies that spoil the conservation of the quantum non-local charges in the CPN−1=SU(N)/SU(N−1)×U(1) models for N>2, and in the wider class of theories based on the complex Grassmannians SU(N)/SU(n)×SU(N−n)×U(1) for N>n>1 [9].

By contrast, calculations using the 1/N expansion reveal anomalies that spoil the conservation of the quantum non-local charges in the CPN−1=SU(N)/SU(N−1)×U(1) models for N>2, and in the wider class of theories based on the complex Grassmannians SU(N)/SU(n)×SU(N−n)×U(1) for N>n>1 [9].

original_annotated_sentences: Classical, two-dimensional sigma models on compact symmetric spaces G/H are integrable by virtue of conserved quantities which can arise as integrals of local or non-local functions of the underlying fields (the accounts in [1–5] contain references to the extensive literature).
Since these models are asymptotically free and strongly coupled in the infrared, their quantum properties are not straightforward to determine.

Nevertheless, following Lüscher [6], Abdalla, Forger and Gomes showed [7] that, in a G/H sigma model with H simple,11Here, and throughout this Letter, we shall use simple to mean that the corresponding Lie algebra has no non-trivial ideals.

Hence U(1) is simple in our terminology, in addition to the usual non-Abelian simple groups of the Cartan–Killing classification [13]. the first conserved non-local charge survives
quantization
(after an appropriate renormalization [6–8]), which suffices to ensure quantum integrability of the theory.

By contrast, calculations using the 1/N expansion reveal anomalies that spoil the conservation of the quantum non-local charges in the CPN−1=SU(N)/SU(N−1)×U(1) models for N>2, and in the wider class of theories based on the complex Grassmannians SU(N)/SU(n)×SU(N−n)×U(1) for N>n>1 [9].

two-dimensional sigma models on compact.translated_key: bidimensionales en espacios simétricos compactos G/H
original_annotated_sentences:
Classical,
two-dimensional sigma models on compact symmetric spaces G/H
are integrable by virtue of conserved quantities which can arise as integrals of local or non-local functions of the underlying fields (the accounts in [1–5] contain references to the extensive literature).
Since these models are asymptotically free and strongly coupled in the infrared, their quantum properties are not straightforward to determine.

Nevertheless, following Lüscher [6], Abdalla, Forger and Gomes showed [7] that, in a G/H sigma model with H simple,11Here, and throughout this Letter, we shall use simple to mean that the corresponding Lie algebra has no non-trivial ideals.

Hence U(1) is simple in our terminology, in addition to the usual non-Abelian simple groups of the Cartan–Killing classification [13]. the first conserved non-local charge survives quantization (after an appropriate renormalization [6–8]), which suffices to ensure quantum integrability of the theory.

By contrast, calculations using the 1/N expansion reveal anomalies that spoil the conservation of the quantum non-local charges in the CPN−1=SU(N)/SU(N−1)×U(1) models for N>2, and in the wider class of theories based on the complex Grassmannians SU(N)/SU(n)×SU(N−n)×U(1) for N>n>1 [9].
original_annotated_samples:
Classical,
two-dimensional sigma models on compact symmetric spaces G/H
are integrable by virtue of conserved quantities which can arise as integrals of local or non-local functions of the underlying fields (the accounts in [1–5] contain references to the extensive literature).
translated_annotated_samples:
Output: Los modelos sigma clásicos,
bidimensionales en espacios simétricos compactos G/H
, son integrables gracias a las cantidades conservadas que pueden surgir como integrales de funciones locales o no locales de los campos subyacentes (los informes en [1-5] contienen referencias a la extensa literatura).
two-dimensional sigma models on compact.translated_text:
Output: Los modelos sigma clásicos,
bidimensionales en espacios simétricos compactos G/H
, son integrables gracias a las cantidades conservadas que pueden surgir como integrales de funciones locales o no locales de los campos subyacentes (los informes en [1-5] contienen referencias a la extensa literatura). Dado que estos modelos son asintóticamente libres y fuertemente acoplados en el infrarrojo, sus propiedades cuánticas no son fáciles de determinar. Sin embargo, siguiendo a Lüscher [6], Abdalla, Forger y Gomes demostraron [7] que, en un modelo sigma G/H con H simple, 11Aquí, y a lo largo de esta carta, usaremos simple para referirnos a que el álgebra de Lie correspondiente no tiene ideales no triviales. Por lo tanto, U(1) es simple en nuestra terminología, además de los habituales grupos simples no abelianos de la clasificación de Cartan-Killing [13]. La primera carga no local conservada sobrevive a la cuantización (después de una renormalización apropiada [6-8]), lo cual es suficiente para garantizar la integrabilidad cuántica de la teoría. Por el contrario, los cálculos utilizando la expansión 1/N revelan anomalías que arruinan la conservación de las cargas cuánticas no locales en los modelos CPN−1=SU(N)/SU(N−1)×U(1) para N>2, y en la amplia clase de teorías basadas en los Grassmannianos complejos SU(N)/SU(n)×SU(N−n)×U(1) para N>n>1 [9].
